title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
The analysis of name usage trends revealed fascinating insights into the popularity of selected names over the years. Examining the historical data for names such as Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul from 1920 to 2000 showcased distinct patterns. While Mary maintained consistent popularity, Martha experienced a decline, and Peter and Paul exhibited fluctuations. Additionally, a closer look at the name ‘Vito’ aligned with the release of the movie “The Godfather” in 1972, indicating a notable surge in popularity around that time. 


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4names/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
The analysis of name usage trends revealed fascinating insights into the popularity of selected names over the years. Examining the historical data for names such as Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul from 1920 to 2000 showcased distinct patterns. While Mary maintained consistent popularity, Martha experienced a decline, and Peter and Paul exhibited fluctuations. Additionally, a closer look at the name ‘Vito’ aligned with the release of the movie “The Godfather” in 1972, indicating a notable surge in popularity around that time. 


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4names/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
My name is Aayush. Because the name is well-known in other parts of the world, it sticks out. The data indicates that it hasn’t been used all that much. When I was born in 2004, there were 39 babies with the name Aayush. Although historically very few people have used the name Aayush, its use peaked in 2010 with 49 people using it. My name was not very common before 2001.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
# pd.unique(df.query('name == "Aayush"').year).size
aayush_data = df[df['name'] == 'Aayush']

# Plot the historical usage of the name
fig = px.line(aayush_data, x='year', y='Total', title='Historical Usage of the Name Aayush')

# Add a vertical line for your birth year
your_birth_year = 2004  
fig.add_shape(
    dict(
        type='line',
        x0=your_birth_year,
        x1=your_birth_year,
        y0=0,
        y1=aayush_data['Total'].max(),
        line=dict(color='red', dash='dash'),
        name='Your Birth Year'
    )
)

fig.add_annotation(
    x=your_birth_year,
    y=aayush_data['Total'].max(),
    text='Birth Year \'2004\'',
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=2,
    arrowcolor='red',
    ax=0,
    ay=-40
)

fig.show()

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
If I talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, my guess of his or her age would be around 34 or 33. The graph indicates that in 1990, this name peaked at around 32k. The individual I spoke with may therefore be in their 30s. After 1990, this name gradually became less common. In a comparable way, I wouldn’t guess that someone with this name is older than 50 because, based on the provided graphs, no one had this name in 1970.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
brittany_data = df[df['name'] == 'Brittany']
fig = px.bar(brittany_data, x='year', y='Total', title='Age Distribution for Brittany')
fig.show()


                                                


_

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
Comparing the popularity of these four Christian names, we can conclude that Mary was the most popular. A peak of 53k was reached by this name in 1950. Out of these four names, Paul is the second most popular and was very well-known from 1950 to 1970. Paul reached about 25k in 1954. Compared to the other two names, Peter and Martha were not in the trends. But in 1956, there were about 10,000 people with the name Peter. In addition, Martha was named roughly 10,000 in 1947. In summary, after the 1950s, the names mentioned above saw a decline in popularity, and by 2000, they had fallen out of popularity.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
names_list = ['Mary', 'Martha', 'Peter', 'Paul']
selected_names_data = df[df['name'].isin(names_list)]
selected_names_data = selected_names_data[(selected_names_data['year'] >= 1920) & (selected_names_data['year'] <= 2000)]
fig = px.line(selected_names_data, x='year', y='Total', color='name', title='Name Usage Comparison (1920 - 2000)')
fig.show()

text:
Experience

Orchestrated nightly custodial responsibilities across 13 specific areas, uniting efforts to uphold cleanliness and hygiene standards, fostering a comfortable and healthy environment through teamwork.
Spearheaded team to surpass cleaning goals, achieving a 18% efficiency boost.
Demonstrated proactive initiative by strictly adhering to safety protocols, resulting in two consecutive accident-free months, ensuring well-being of all team members

Managed a diverse collection of over 15 library resources, accessibility and organizational efficiency.
Initiated and oversaw a total of 22 library programs, led to a remarkable 18% increase in participation, engaging community in a variety of enriching activities and events.


Skills
Languages: Python, Java. Web Programming: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React.Js, Node.Js. Databases: MySQL, MongoDB. Others: Git, GitHub, Linux, Microsoft Office Suite.


Projects

Aug 2023 - Dec 2023 Designer/Developer | BYU-Idaho Apartment Website,

Transformed housing search platforms, enhancing way information is delivered and streamlining user experience.

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?
One of the characters in the 1972 film “The Godfather” was called Vito. There were  persons named Vito in 19. But by 1940, things had drastically changed, and the data had reached _. In 1972, this name was only used by . Vito’s name began to progressively fade after the film’s release. _


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
movie_release_year = 1972
unique_name = 'Vito'

vito_data = df[df['name'] == unique_name]

fig = px.line(vito_data, x='year', y='Total', title=f'Name Usage Over Time for {unique_name}')
fig.update_layout(
    shapes=[
        dict(
            type='line',
            x0=movie_release_year,
            x1=movie_release_year,
            y0=0,
            y1=vito_data['Total'].max(),
            line=dict(color='red', dash='dash'),
            name='Movie Release Year'
        )
    ]
)

fig.add_annotation(
    x=movie_release_year,
    y=vito_data['Total'].max(),
    text='Movie Release year \'1972\'',
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=2,
    arrowcolor='red',
    ax=0,
    ay=-40
)
fig.show()
